7.30.19  7:43 am   thoughts on chord inversions?

      each one sounds different, and would therefore invoke different thoughts. actually, they don't even invoke thoughts, they only contain feelings, and then when they are paired with something else (besides a chord) those feelings + other thing can trigger the thoughts. they are usually very interesting and good thoughts, drenched with much feeling (due to chord)

7.30.19  2:32 am   why would you voice something in second inversion, like Bma7/F#, for example? does that all have to do with the chords and voice leading around it? also how would you voice that on keys

      it just sounds a little different. you'll have to try it and see. actually i can give you a really common example of where B/F# really is what you want. actually let's switch it to the key of C for easier explaining, and it's not actually Cmaj7/G, this example is C/G, but nonetheless i think you will be able to see the difference. Take the song 'happy birthday to you' in the key of C. right before the end of the song, on the last "birth". the harmony is probably playing C chord, but i think you'll find that the best place for the bass, at this point in the song, is G. i can name a trillion other examples of popular/classic/traditional songs, over the course of the last 300 years, that have had a 1(chord) over 5(bass) absolutely thrive in this right before the end finalistic 'the song's about to end' spot. you've heard it a million times. try putting C over C there instead .... it doesn't quite fit. it sounds like the beginning of the song, .... right before the end ? ... By the way, to complete the example just you you can hear it clearly, the 'good' way to do it, from the final line "birth" is C/G, "day" is D7, "to" is G7sus4, and "you" is C, preferably with the G note left out, just e c , with low C in the bass. and Fmin/Ab was on "hap"

7.29.19  2:54 pm   so i've started analyzing hymns from this baptist hymnal and it's got me thinking why specific voicings don't have names.

     they might, in the context of whichever songwriters where writing that way at the time. but it's all just notes anyway

      i don't know if im wrong about this, but like i came across a voicing of G major(In G) like root, 5th, root, 3rd and although i understand that's just "G major" why hasn't anyone invented a naming system to differentiate all these different voicings that exist? have you ever invented one?

     i think the truly 2 most efficient ways i know of notating that are this and this. or better yet this. or this

7.29.19  12:26 am   how does one stop being the kind of guy who wants to follow 24/7 news coverage of the most recent tragic event.

     it's quite simple really. learn how to mechanically power-off your news device, and completely de-activate it, and store it away completely out of use. in about 5 days you will no longer be hooked on it, and you will likely have become hooked on something different instead. maybe even more enjoyable
